column2: Introduction to HTML
What you'll do
Learn the basics of web pages and the language they're written in  - HTML. (Part 1)
Hi, *{{user_name}}*! I know you've used the internet before - but have you ever wondered what goes into showing you all those web pages?
I was wondering that, one day, and I decided to go find out. There was a ton to learn, but now that I've done the legwork, I can pass it on to you.
Before I explain anything, let's get you looking at the guts of a web page.
The page should open for you, but if it doesn't, you can try running Chrome...
...Or you can click this link: https://codepen.io/madetohack/pen/BaaNeXj?editors=1000#code-area
OK! Here we are. One half of your browser is showing you the code that the page is written in...
...And the other half is what you'd see if you found this page on the internet.
If you want to see things side-by-side, you can click the *Change View* button in the upper right, and change the *Editor Layout* to a different one.
You might need to resize Chrome's window to find that button, so just click the arrows between the minimize button and the X to let you do that.
Just like computer programs, web pages are written in a kind of code - It's called HTML.
You put HTML around text, and that tells your web browser what to show, and how to show it on your screen. Not so bad, right?
In HTML, everything with *<* and *>* around it is called a *tag*. Tags tell the browser how to display something - text, images, whatever.
Tags usually come in pairs - an *<opening tag>*, and a *</closing tag>*, like saying *start* and *stop*
Let's get our hands dirty! Find the text *Hello, World!* on the page, and change it. Add your name, your favorite food, whatever you like.
Awesome! You just edited a webpage, so that makes you a web designer!
Let's take it one step further - see the *<h1>* tags in the code? Try changing the text between them...
Nice job! HTML isn't as confusing as it looks, right?. Come back to continue the adventure, and we'll go deeper!
